title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #780: Chromatic Number of Kneser Hypergraphs**

If n ≥ kr + (t-1)(k-1), any t-coloring of r-sets has k monochromatic disjoint edges.

**Status:** SOLVED (Alon-Frankl-Lovász 1986)
**Special case k=2:** Kneser's conjecture, proved by Lovász 1978
mathContext: The Kneser hypergraph KG^r(n,k) has r-subsets as vertices and k-tuples of disjoint r-sets as edges.

title: Pairwise Disjoint Edges
content:
**PairwiseDisjoint:** A set of hyperedges is pairwise disjoint if no two share a vertex.

This forms a matching in the hypergraph. The problem asks for k such edges in one color.

title: The Threshold Function
content:
**threshold k r t:** n₀ = kr + (t-1)(k-1)

This is the exact threshold. For n ≥ n₀, a monochromatic k-matching exists. For n < n₀, a coloring avoiding it exists.

title: Alon-Frankl-Lovász (1986)
content:
**alon_frankl_lovasz_1986:** The main theorem.

For n ≥ kr + (t-1)(k-1), any t-coloring of the complete r-uniform hypergraph contains a monochromatic k-matching.

Proved using topological methods (Borsuk-Ulam theorem).

title: Tightness Construction
content:
**tightness_construction:** The bound is optimal.

For n = kr - 1 + (t-1)(k-1), partition [n] = X₁ ∪ X₂ ∪ ... ∪ Xₜ where |X₁| = kr-1 and |Xᵢ| = k-1.

Color by first non-empty intersection. This avoids k disjoint monochromatic edges.

title: Kneser's Conjecture (k=2)
content:
**kneser_conjecture:** χ(KG(n,r)) = n - 2r + 2 for n ≥ 2r.

This is the k=2 case of the general theorem. Conjectured by Kneser (1955), proved by Lovász (1978).

Example: χ(KG(5,2)) = 3 (Petersen graph).

title: Lovász's Proof (1978)
content:
**lovasz_1978:** Revolutionary use of the Borsuk-Ulam theorem.

This was the first major application of algebraic topology to a combinatorial problem, establishing topological combinatorics as a field.

title: Borsuk-Ulam Theorem
content:
**borsuk_ulam_theorem:** No continuous antipodal map Sⁿ → Sⁿ⁻¹ exists.

If f: Sⁿ → ℝⁿ is continuous, then f(x) = f(-x) for some x.

This is the key topological tool in the proof.

title: The Petersen Graph
content:
**petersen_chromatic:** KG(5,2) is the Petersen graph with χ = 3.

Vertices are 2-subsets of {1,2,3,4,5}. Adjacent if disjoint.

This is the most famous example of a Kneser graph.

title: Erdős-Ko-Rado Connection
content:
**erdos_ko_rado:** Maximum intersecting family of r-subsets of [n] has size C(n-1,r-1) for n ≥ 2r.

This equals the independence number of the Kneser graph.

Intersecting families are independent sets in KG(n,r).

title: Main Result Summary
content:
**erdos_780_main:** Complete statement of the Alon-Frankl-Lovász theorem.

For n ≥ kr + (t-1)(k-1), any t-coloring of r-subsets of [n] contains k pairwise disjoint subsets of the same color.

Status: SOLVED
